alert.note: Alert for Haywood; Madison; Mitchell; Yancey (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued January 16 at 3:46AM EST until January 16 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 AM EST THIS MORNING... ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO NOON EST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, mixed precipitation. Additional snow accumulations of a dusting to one inch are expected through daybreak. Ice accumulations will range from a light glaze to a few hundredths of an inch. Icy and snow covered roadways will continue. For the Wind Chill Advisory, very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills will fall to 5 to 15 below zero, with values of minus 15 to minus 25 at the highest peaks. * WHERE...Madison, Yancey, Mitchell and Haywood Counties. * WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 7 AM EST this morning. For the Wind Chill Advisory, from 2 PM this afternoon to noon EST Wednesday. Precipitation will taper off to flurries after 7 am EST. * IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute. The cold wind chills could result in hypothermia if precautions are not taken. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Although the Winter Weather Advisory will likely be allowed to expire at 7 am EST this morning, A Special Weather Statement will likely be issued for ongoing very hazardous road conditions due to the ice, snow, and very cold temperatures. Ice and snow covered roadways may persist into Wednesday or longer.
info.instruction: A Winter Weather Advisory means that periods of snow, sleet, or freezing rain will cause travel difficulties. Be prepared for slippery roads and limited visibilities, and use caution while driving. A Wind Chill Advisory means that very cold air and strong winds will combine to generate low wind chills. This will result in frost bite and lead to hypothermia if precautions are not taken. If you must venture outdoors, make sure you wear a hat and gloves. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your favorite source of weather information for the latest updates. Additional details can be found at www.weather.gov/gsp. The latest state road conditions can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
